prompt.text: The graph of $f$ is shown. What is $\lim_{x\to 2} f(x)$?

options.explanation: From the left, $f(x)$ approaches $3$. From the right, the graph is at $y=3$ near $x=2$. Both one-sided limits match.
$f(2)=1$ is the filled point, but the limit depends on nearby values, not the value at $x=2$.
The one-sided limits are equal here, so the two-sided limit exists.
There is no evidence the function approaches $2$ from either side near $x=2$.

explanation: Read the approach values on both sides of $x=2$. The left-hand limit is $3$ and the right-hand limit is also $3$, so $\lim_{x\to 2} f(x)=3$.
micro_explanations: Identify the y-value approached as $x\to 2^-$.
Identify the y-value approached as $x\to 2^+$.
If they match, that common value is the limit.
recommendation_reasons: Targets connecting graphical behavior to two-sided limits.
Reinforces difference between $f(2)$ and $\lim_{x\to 2} f(x)$.
notes: Chapter 1.9 Connecting Multiple Representations of Limits
title: U1C9Q1_Limit_Consistent_With_Graph

prompt.text: A function satisfies $f(x)=(x-3)(x+1)$ for $x\ne 3$, and $f(3)=10$. What is $\lim_{x\to 3} f(x)$?

options.explanation: $10$ is $f(3)$, but the limit uses values near $3$, and the formula for $x\ne 3$ controls the approach.

This is the value of $(x-3)(x+1)$ at $x=3$, but $(x-3)$ makes it $0$ only if substituted directly; the expression is defined for $x\ne 3$, yet the limit can still be found by substitution into the polynomial.
$4$ is $x+1$ at $x=3$, but you must multiply by the factor approaching $0$.

explanation: For $x\ne 3$, $f(x)$ equals a polynomial. Polynomials are continuous, so the limit equals the polynomial value at $x=3$: $(3-3)(3+1)=0$.
micro_explanations: Use the given expression valid for $x\ne 3$ to analyze approach behavior.
Polynomials have limits equal to their substituted values.
Compare with $f(3)$ to avoid confusing value with limit.
recommendation_reasons: Connects symbolic definition with the idea that the limit can exist even if the function value is redefined.
Common AP trap: mixing $f(a)$ with $\lim_{x\to a} f(x)$.
notes: Chapter 1.9 Connecting Multiple Representations of Limits
title: U1C9Q2_Limit_Using_Symbolic_With_Redefinition

prompt.text: A table gives values of $g(x)$ near $x=1$. For $x<1$, the values trend toward $2$. For $x>1$, the values trend toward $-1$. Which statement is true?

options.explanation: This matches only the left-hand trend, not the right-hand trend.
This matches only the right-hand trend, not the left-hand trend.
The table trends do not determine $g(1)$ unless a value at $x=1$ is provided.
The one-sided limits approach different values ($2$ vs. $-1$), so the two-sided limit does not exist.

explanation: A two-sided limit exists only if the left-hand and right-hand limits are equal. Here they differ, so $\lim_{x\to 1} g(x)$ does not exist.
micro_explanations: Identify the left-hand approach value from the table trend.
Identify the right-hand approach value from the table trend.
Different one-sided limits imply DNE.
recommendation_reasons: Forces explicit one-sided reasoning from a representation other than a graph.
High-frequency error: declaring the more 'stable-looking' side as the limit.
notes: Chapter 1.9 Connecting Multiple Representations of Limits
title: U1C9Q3_Connect_Table_To_OneSided_Limits

prompt.text: The table shown gives values of $f(x)$ near $x=2$. Estimate $\lim_{x\to 2} f(x)$.

options.explanation: That is $f(1.9)$, not the value approached near $x=2$.
The values $3.9601$ and $4.0401$ cluster around $4$, suggesting the limit is $4$.
That is $f(2.1)$, which is farther from $2$ than $2.01$.
The table suggests approach toward a single value from both sides, so the limit exists.

explanation: As $x$ gets closer to $2$ from both sides, $f(x)$ gets closer to $4$, so $\lim_{x\to 2} f(x)\approx 4$.
micro_explanations: Focus on inputs closest to $2$ on each side.
Compare the corresponding outputs.
Pick the common target value.
recommendation_reasons: Builds quick table-to-limit estimation used throughout Unit 1.
Reinforces choosing the closest x-values over farther ones.
notes: Chapter 1.9 Connecting Multiple Representations of Limits
title: U1C9Q4_Limit_From_Table_At_2

prompt.text: Define $h(x)=\dfrac{|x-2|}{x-2}$ for $x\ne 2$. Which statement is true?

options.explanation: The function takes values $-1$ or $1$, never approaching $0$ near $2$.
The right-hand limit is $1$, but the left-hand limit is $-1$.
For $x>2$, $h(x)=1$; for $x<2$, $h(x)=-1$. The one-sided limits differ.

explanation: Compute one-sided behavior: if $x>2$, then $|x-2|=x-2$ so $h(x)=1$. If $x<2$, then $|x-2|=-(x-2)$ so $h(x)=-1$. Since $1\ne -1$, the two-sided limit does not exist.
micro_explanations: Rewrite $|x-2|$ piecewise for $x>2$ and $x<2$.
Evaluate left-hand and right-hand limits separately.
Conclude DNE if they differ.
recommendation_reasons: Connects symbolic piecewise reasoning to limit existence.
High-discrimination AP item: absolute value in a limit context.
notes: Chapter 1.9 Connecting Multiple Representations of Limits
title: U1C9Q5_Connect_AbsoluteValue_To_OneSided

prompt.text: The graph of $f$ is shown. What type of discontinuity does $f$ have at $x=1$?

options.explanation: A removable discontinuity would have matching one-sided limits. Here the left and right behaviors do not approach the same value.
An infinite discontinuity requires unbounded behavior near $x=1$, which is not shown.
The left and right sides do not meet at one common value.
The left-hand limit and right-hand limit are finite but unequal, indicating a jump.

explanation: At $x=1$, the graph approaches one finite value from the left and a different finite value from the right, so the discontinuity is a jump discontinuity.
micro_explanations: Check whether the left-hand and right-hand limits exist.
Decide whether they are equal.
Finite but unequal implies jump.
recommendation_reasons: Core classification skill for discontinuities.
Trains reading discontinuity type directly from a graph.
title: U1C10Q1_Classify_Discontinuity_From_Graph

prompt.text: Consider $p(x)=\dfrac{x^2-9}{x-3}$ for $x\ne 3$. What must $p(3)$ be to make $p$ continuous at $x=3$?

options.explanation: The limiting value is not $0$; simplify first to find the limit.
After simplification, the limit at $x=3$ is $6$, so setting $p(3)=6$ fills the removable discontinuity.
This is the x-value, not the y-value that continuity requires.
This is a removable discontinuity, so defining the function at $x=3$ can make it continuous.

micro_explanations: Factor the numerator.
Cancel $(x-3)$ for $x\ne 3$ to get the simplified form.
Set $p(3)$ equal to the limit value.
recommendation_reasons: Classic removable discontinuity completion problem.
Directly connects algebraic limit to continuity definition.
title: U1C10Q2_Remove_Discontinuity_By_Definition

prompt.text: The graph of $f$ is shown. Which statement is true?

latex: $$\text{Choose the correct statement about limits near }x=0.$$

options.explanation: The function values do not approach $0$; they grow without bound in magnitude.
On the left side the graph goes to $-\infty$, not $+\infty$.
The left branch goes downward without bound and the right branch goes upward without bound, indicating a vertical asymptote at $x=0$.
The function is unbounded near $x=0$, so a finite two-sided limit cannot exist.

explanation: From the graph, as $x\to 0^-$ the function decreases without bound, and as $x\to 0^+$ it increases without bound. So there is an infinite discontinuity (vertical asymptote) at $x=0$.
micro_explanations: Read the end behavior on each side of the vertical line $x=0$.
Record each one-sided infinite limit with the correct sign.
Conclude vertical asymptote from infinite behavior.
recommendation_reasons: Tests sign awareness for infinite limits.
Common error: assuming both sides go to the same infinity.
title: U1C10Q3_Infinite_Limit_And_Asymptote

prompt.text: At $x=a$, a function has $\lim_{x\to a^-} f(x)=5$ and $\lim_{x\to a^+} f(x)=5$, but $f(a)$ is not defined. What type of discontinuity is at $x=a$?

options.explanation: The two-sided limit exists and is finite, but the function value is missing, so defining $f(a)=5$ would make it continuous.
A jump requires unequal one-sided limits.
Infinite discontinuities involve unbounded limits.
Continuity also requires $f(a)$ to exist and equal the limit.

explanation: Equal finite one-sided limits imply the (two-sided) limit exists. Because $f(a)$ is undefined, the discontinuity can be removed by defining $f(a)=5$.
micro_explanations: Check whether the one-sided limits match.
If they match and are finite, the limit exists.
Missing or mismatched function value implies removable discontinuity.
recommendation_reasons: Fast classification using limit facts alone.
Reinforces the 3-part continuity idea implicitly.
title: U1C10Q4_Classify_Removable_From_Limit_Facts

prompt.text: A function $f$ has $\lim_{x\to 4^-} f(x)=2$ and $\lim_{x\to 4^+} f(x)=2$. Also $f(4)=7$. Which statement is true?

options.text: $f$ is continuous at $x=4$ because both one-sided limits exist
options.explanation: Continuity also requires $f(4)$ to equal the limit.
The limit is determined by nearby behavior, and both sides approach $2$, not $7$.
The limit exists and equals $2$, but $f(4)=7\ne 2$, so redefining $f(4)$ to $2$ would make it continuous.
A jump requires different left- and right-hand limits; here they are equal.

explanation: Since $\lim_{x\to 4^-} f(x)=\lim_{x\to 4^+} f(x)=2$, the two-sided limit exists and equals $2$. But $f(4)=7\ne 2$, so the discontinuity is removable.
micro_explanations: Equal one-sided limits imply $\lim_{x\to 4} f(x)=2$.
Compare $f(4)$ to the limit.
Mismatch implies discontinuity; since the limit exists, it is removable.
recommendation_reasons: High-frequency AP concept: removable discontinuity caused by a misdefined point value.
Separates 'limit exists' from 'function is continuous'.
title: U1C10Q5_Removable_When_Value_Differs_From_Limit
